290. Scambler, Margaret A. (Mrs. W.R.)
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Mrs. Margaret A. Scammon
Address: Clair, Sask.
Birthplace: Emerson, Manitoba

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1910
Where did you set up housekeeping? He 22 - 88 - 15 W 2nd
Where had you been living before that? Clair
For how many people did you prepare meals? 7
How far was it to your nearest store? Eighteen miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Very necessary
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Sugar, tea, fruit, salt, spices, dried fruits, cheese etc.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Ogilvie
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lb. bags
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $3.25
How much did you use graham flour? Very little
Whole wheat flour? None
Was flour milled locally? Yes How far away? .......... What year? .......
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? .............
What other grain products did you use? Palomino
Cornmeal? A little Whole Wheat? No Farina? 2 lbs.
Other? ..............................................................
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? ...........................................

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

The most difference in wrapping in the past and present is in the use of plastic containers.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Our first year on homestead day for the month of June. Breakfast: bacon & eggs, jam & fruit bread & butter & tea. Dinner: roast beef & gravy, vegetables, baked potato, dessert & tea. Supper: 6 PM, egg & cold meat, warmed & scalloped potatoes, fruit & cake & coffee. Hot all days were the same.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in western Canada? Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

Our first Christmas dinner was 1905 in our house at Blair. Cannot remember in detail. Had roast turkey & goose with mince pie & Christmas cake candy out of fruit. Present were parents, family of mine ranging from 24-6/24 yrs. Also 2 Uncle and neighboring bachelors.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No. Always had plenty except for one winter could not get sugar & yeast cakes for a month or so due to the snow blocking the C.M.R.
16. Mention any changes which you found in the appearance and containers of the food you purchased.

The great difference in appearance in the past and present is in the use of plastic containers.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can recall. Give the names of the family members who ate with their guests, if any.

Sunfish soup on Christmas Day. Dinner at 4 o'clock.

18. That year did you serve your first Christmas dinner? In what town?

That year did you serve your first Christmas dinner? In what town?

19. Have you ever refused to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

20. Always had plenty except for one winter would not get enough our yard cake for a month or so due to the snow.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Being a farmer most of my life, the present trend to prepared foods does not affect us as city dwellers. It is very convenient to open cans and have them cooked our morning cereal and lunch. Easier opening a can of milk than milking the cows (though not so good).

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

In 1946 when we retired from farming.
